home.whoAmI:
**Senior Frontend Architect** & **Software Crafter** from Spain with over **10 years of experience**. Freelancer _obsessed_ with **best practices**, **architecture** and **testing**.

As an [international speaker](https://www.cesalberca.com/talks) and Digital Nomad, I share my tech adventures around the world. Active in the [Codemotion](https://www.codemotion.com/) community as a committee member and [ambassador](https://community-en.codemotion.it/community/ambassador-program). Host of [Colivers Club Podcast](https://coliversclub.com/).

projects.title: Projects
projects.description: I love to create projects to learn new technologies and to share knowledge. Here are some of the projects I've created.
projects.katasDescription: **TDD** and **testing** are very important to me. Whenever I taught a course about programming, I needed to create the same exercises over and over again. So, I decided to abstract it into a project where my students could practice **TDD**, **testing**, and **TypeScript** through simple and useful **Katas**.
projects.blogDescription: My personal site, crafted with the latest technologies and best practices. It's built with **Next.js**, **React**, **TypeScript**, **TailwindCSS** and **Framer Motion**.
projects.archimedesJsDescription: A **TypeScript** library I created that helps you create robust applications by leveraging use cases. It helps you create **modular architectures** following **hexagonal** and **domain-driven design** principles.
projects.moreProjects: You can also [check out my Github](https://github.com/cesalberca/), where I have more than 70 open source projects.

isabel.name: Isabel Rodríguez
isabel.content:
I had the pleasure of meeting César when he was just starting his career—very young but full of energy and eager to learn. From the beginning, he stood out for his commitment and enthusiasm for sharing his knowledge with others, qualities that have always been his greatest strengths.

Over time, César has become a respected figure in the industry, thanks to his continuous training and dedication to developing high-quality software. He has always been willing to take on every task and project I proposed to him, approaching them with a proactive and collaborative attitude. His ability to take on challenges, along with his generosity in sharing what he knows, make him a valuable professional and an excellent colleague.

german.name: Germán Delgado García
german.content:
I have had the privilege of working with César, who is a software development reference. His deep knowledge of software architecture and design is impressive. I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to learn a lot from him, both on the job and in the conferences he has given.

César is curious, funny and intelligent. What stands out most about him is his generosity in sharing his knowledge and experience with others. He is not only a highly skilled professional, but also a person who inspires continuous growth and improvement.

If you are looking for someone who combines great technical skills with the ability to communicate and teach clearly and effectively, César is the person for you. I am sure he will be a valuable addition to any team.

francisco.name: Francisco Picolini
francisco.content:
I had the pleasure of collaborating with César during my time managing the Conference content for Codemotion Madrid. César played a crucial role in shaping the agenda, particularly by selecting top-notch frontend proposals, which is his area of expertise. He also contributed beyond this by suggesting innovative topics and recommending talented speakers.

Not only is César a highly engaging and skilled speaker, but he is also a dedicated team player who consistently goes above and beyond to ensure project success. His deep knowledge of modern frameworks and emerging technologies is impressive, and he has a genuine passion for sharing that expertise with others.

César is a complete developer—always well-informed, forward-thinking, and eager to contribute to the success of the team. He's a true asset to any project or organization.

alberto.name: Alberto Chamorro
alberto.content:
César is a great person, developer, and colleague with whom I had the pleasure of working at Autentia. During the time I worked with him, he demonstrated strong capabilities in facing various technical challenges, consistently creating effective and creative solutions that always added significant value for the client.

I can confidently say that César possesses solid knowledge not only in the technological field but also in software architecture and design. Additionally, his hunger for knowledge, combined with his eagerness to share it, makes César a highly valuable asset for any team or challenge he takes on.

carlos.name: Carlos Blé
carlos.content: César is a kind and friendly person with a great sense of humor, and, of course, he is an excellent professional. Highly intelligent, very capable, and extremely hardworking. Years ago, I had the chance to have him as an outstanding student in several of my courses, and I was impressed by his ability and eagerness to learn. César is a professional with common sense and exceptional technical quality.

antonio.name: Antonio Cobo Cuenca
antonio.content: César and I served on a conference program committee together for several years. I consistently relied on his deep understanding of the latest trends in the Front End world. During our discussions about improving the conference, I was impressed by his critical thinking skills and his ability to see the big picture. César considers every angle of a problem and consistently finds the right solution.

adrian.name: Adrián Ferrera
adrian.content:
I had the privilege of meeting César Alberca years ago, and since then he has been a constant reference in my professional development. Although we have not worked together on direct projects, our collaboration in conferences, coding dojos, and debates on architecture and software design has been invaluable.

His passion for best practices, architecture, and testing is evident in every project he undertakes. Furthermore, his focus on architectural patterns such as DDD and hexagonal design demonstrates his commitment to software quality and scalability.

What really distinguishes César is his drive for improvement and his generosity in sharing knowledge. As a speaker at conferences and an active member of the community, he has positively influenced many professionals in the field. His ability to teach and his collaborative attitude make him an exceptional learning companion.

If you are looking for someone with a solid technical foundation, a passion for continuous learning, and a positive and collaborative attitude, do not hesitate to connect with César. I am sure he will be a valuable addition to any team or project.

about.title: About me
about.description:
I'm a self-learner, creative, enthusiastic, and passionate person. I have a mixed profile, divided between my love for programming, software architecture, and design. I truly care about sharing knowledge with my peers, whether as a speaker at various technological events, as a teacher, or through my social networks.

I believe that Software should be robust yet flexible, and the way to achieve it is – regardless of the framework – to create the right abstractions and apply architectural patterns. Testing is very important to me; the Software we build should be reliable in order to provide the maximum value.

cost.question: How much does it cost?
cost.answer: How much money are you willing to lose by not implementing best practices?

remoteWork.question: Do you work with remote teams?
remoteWork.answer: Absolutely! As a digital nomad, I'm experienced in working with distributed teams across different time zones. I use collaborative tools and regular communication to ensure smooth project delivery regardless of location.

frameworks.question: What frameworks do you specialize in?
frameworks.answer: I have extensive experience with React (5+ years), Angular (4+ years), and Vue (2+ years). However, my architectural expertise transcends specific frameworks, focusing on patterns and practices that can be applied across technologies.

knowledgeTransfer.question: How do you handle knowledge transfer?
knowledgeTransfer.answer: Knowledge transfer is built into my process. I provide comprehensive documentation, conduct training sessions, and offer post-project support to ensure your team fully understands the implemented architecture and can maintain it independently.

approach.question: What makes your architectural approach different?
approach.answer: My approach combines Domain-Driven Design with Hexagonal Architecture to create systems that are both business-aligned and technically robust. I focus on creating clear boundaries between your core domain and external dependencies, making your codebase more maintainable and adaptable to change.

existingCodebase.question: Can you help with an existing codebase?
existingCodebase.answer: Absolutely. I specialize in refactoring and improving existing codebases. I'll analyze your current architecture, identify pain points, and create a strategic plan to incrementally improve your system without disrupting ongoing development. This approach allows you to gradually adopt better practices while continuing to deliver business value.

ongoingSupport.question: Do you offer ongoing support after project completion?
ongoingSupport.answer: Yes, I offer flexible support options after the initial engagement. This can include code reviews, architecture guidance for new features, or regular check-ins to ensure your team is following the established patterns. My goal is to ensure long-term success, not just deliver a solution and walk away.

projectTime.question: How long does a typical project take?
projectTime.answer: Project timelines vary based on scope and complexity. Consultations typically range from 2-4 weeks, while full development projects may take 3-6 months. I'll provide a detailed timeline during our initial consultation.

cookies.title: Cookie Policy
cookies.fullContent:
This website uses cookies to enhance your browsing experience and analyze the effectiveness of our advertising campaigns. Cookies are small text files stored on your device when you visit a website. Some cookies are essential, while others require your consent.

## Google Ads Cookies

We only use cookies from Google Ads for marketing and analytics purposes. These cookies help us understand how you interact with our ads and which pages you visit after clicking on an ad. This allows us to measure the performance of our advertising and optimize our campaigns.

These cookies are **only set if you provide explicit consent** via the cookie banner. They are never loaded before you make a choice.

You can learn more about Google Ads cookies by visiting [Google's Privacy & Terms](https://policies.google.com/technologies/partner-sites).

## Managing Your Preferences

You can accept or reject cookies when you first visit the site. If you change your mind later, you can update your preferences by clicking the **"Manage Cookies"** link in the footer. This will reopen the consent banner and allow you to adjust your settings.

Please note that disabling cookies may affect the functionality and experience of our website.

softwareCafrers.title: Software Craftless: Writing Code That Would Make a Goat Vomit

synopsis.title: Synopsis
synopsis.paragraph1: This book has reached you for a very specific reason: the code you write is... _Terrible_. _Shameful_. _Offensive_. **And on top of that, it's in JavaScript**. So yes, this book is for you. So that you keep writing code that only _"works"_ on your local machine and nobody knows why. **Because if nobody understands your code... You're indispensable**.
synopsis.paragraph2: With this book you'll learn to create **undetectable _bugs_**, **infinite recursive nested loops**, code structures that are **illegal in 42 countries**, abstractions that only **a lizard would understand** and functions that return anxiety.
synopsis.paragraph3: In short, you'll reinforce your mastery in **writing code that would make a goat vomit** to become an authentic development brute: a **"Software Cafrer"**. And yes, it's a good gift for that person who does _"that thing"_ with computers and you don't like _that_ much.

biography.title: Biography
biography.paragraph1: **César Alberca** is a **Frontend** **Software** **Architect**, based in Spain, with more than **10 years of experience**. Phew, how serious this sounds... _better in first person?_ Since I'm writing it myself, after all. Okay. I'm very interested in **architecture**, **best practices**, **testing** and creating _Frontend_ applications that **survive the terrible pieces of code you make**. Yes, _you_, the one reading this. You know _perfectly_ well that you've been making code that would knock down a wildebeest for years. When are you going to stop?
biography.paragraph2: Meanwhile, I continue with my thing, promoting job intrusion by giving technical talks about architecture in the _Frontend_ —also called **architecturras™**—, traveling beyond my means as a **digital nomad**, and accumulating hobbies in the hope of forgetting that, _indeed_, **I still program for a living**.
biography.paragraph3: I wish a modal would appear in this book announcing my website. Since that's not the case, I'll leave it here: https://cesalberca.com/
